commit_message:
Neutron LBaaS: Initial Pools Test Client

Client for use in testing pools

Change-Id: I501a4ed7244d5db41e7204aa2ceffd660769a594
Co-Authored-By: Carlos D. Garza <carlos.garza@rackspace.com>
Co-Authored-By: Franklin Naval <franklin.naval@RACKSPACE.COM>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/99/152999/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Rackspace # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import urllib from oslo.serialization import jsonutils from tempest.common import service_client class PoolsClientJSON(service_client.ServiceClient): """ Test Pools API """ def list_pools(self, params=None): """List all pools""" url = 'pools' if params: url = '{0}?{1}'.format(url, urllib.urlencode(params)) resp, body = self.get(url) body = jsonutils.loads(body) self.expected_success(200, resp.status) return service_client.ResponseBodyList(resp, body['pools']) def get_pool(self, pool_id, params=None): """List details of a pool""" url = 'pools/{pool_id}'.format(pool_id=pool_id) if params: url = '{0}?{1}'.format(url, urllib.urlencode(params)) resp, body = self.get(url) body = jsonutils.loads(body) self.expected_success(200, resp.status) return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body['pool']) def create_pool(self, **kwargs): """Create a pool""" url = 'pools' post_body = jsonutils.dumps({'pool': kwargs}) resp, body = self.post(url, post_body) body = jsonutils.loads(body) self.expected_success(202, resp.status) return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body['pool']) def update_pool(self, pool_id, **kwargs): """Update a pool""" url = 'pools/{pool_id}'.format(pool_id=pool_id) post_body = jsonutils.dumps({'pool': kwargs}) resp, body = self.post(url, post_body) body = jsonutils.loads(body) self.expected_success(202, resp.status) return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body['pool']) def delete_pool(self, pool_id): """Delete Pool""" url = 'pools/{pool_id}'.format(pool_id=pool_id) resp, body = self.delete(url) self.expected_success(204, resp.status) return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body)

commit_message:
Enable nova-api-metadata for multi host nova-network

This adds nova-api-metadata to the list of enabled services that
run on the sub node, required for serving metadata if config drive
gets disabled to support live migration.

Change-Id: Ibe4e9e6337d5447e186117510b20fd517af2f3b9

commit_message:
Enable nova multi host on aiopcpu tests

Nova multi host is not something we can test in the normal all in one
devstack + tempest tests. Configure multi host on the 2 node devstack
and tempest test setups to cover this code.

Change-Id: I334c525c3678a230a197f0536e9d182f97ed7411

commit_message:
Diagram the nova net multinode network setup

The nova net multinode network setup is relatively non trivial and a
good diagram goes a long way to helping understand what the network
looks like. Add some ascii art that depicts the network setup to aid in
documentation.

Change-Id: If6ef61b664baec1a6e46eed99f4f2b61f3f29358

commit_message:
Separate public and flat interfaces for multinode

Expand the nova network gre bridging used in aiopcpu testing to create
two layer two networks. Without this nova's networking sets up ebtables
such that the two layer 3 networks cannot talk properly on the same
layer 2 gre setup.

Change-Id: I814d234bc30d67af40c2fe55be90a5e6b0024135
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/93/153093/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # flat_if_name: Interface name on each host for the "flat" network # pub_if_name: Interface name on each host for the "public" network. # IPv4 addresses will be assigned to these interfaces using # the details provided below.# note that two keys are used for each subnode. one for flat # interface and the other for the pub interface. # pub_addr_prefix: The IPv4 address three octet prefix used to give compute # nodes non conflicting addresses on the pub_if_name'd # network. Should be provided as X.Y.Z. Offset will be # applied to this as well as the below mask to get the # resulting address. # pub_addr_mask: the CIDR mask less the '/' for the IPv4 addresses used # above. local flat_if_name=$1 local pub_if_name=$2 local offset=$3 local pub_addr_prefix=$4 local pub_addr_mask=$5 local host_ip=$6 shift 6 sudo brctl addbr gre_${flat_if_name}_br sudo brctl addbr gre_${pub_if_name}_br sudo ip link add gretap_${flat_if_name}${key} type gretap local $host_ip remote $node key $key sudo ip link set gretap_${flat_if_name}${key} up remote_command $node sudo -i ip link add ${flat_if_name} type gretap local $node remote $host_ip key $key remote_command $node sudo -i ip link set ${flat_if_name} up sudo brctl addif gre_${flat_if_name}_br gretap_${flat_if_name}${key} (( key++ )) sudo ip link add gretap_${pub_if_name}${key} type gretap local $host_ip remote $node key $key sudo ip link set gretap_${pub_if_name}${key} up remote_command $node sudo -i ip link add ${pub_if_name} type gretap local $node remote $host_ip key $key remote_command $node sudo -i ip link set ${pub_if_name} up remote_command $node sudo -i ip address add ${pub_addr_prefix}.${key}/${pub_addr_mask} brd + dev ${pub_if_name} sudo brctl addif gre_${pub_if_name}_br gretap_${pub_if_name}${key} sudo ip link add ${flat_if_name}_br_if type veth peer name ${flat_if_name} sudo brctl addif gre_${flat_if_name}_br ${flat_if_name}_br_if sudo ip link set ${flat_if_name}_br_if up sudo ip link set ${flat_if_name} up sudo ip link set gre_${flat_if_name}_br up sudo ip link add ${pub_if_name}_br_if type veth peer name ${pub_if_name} sudo brctl addif gre_${pub_if_name}_br ${pub_if_name}_br_if sudo ip link set ${pub_if_name}_br_if up sudo ip link set ${pub_if_name} up sudo ip link set gre_${pub_if_name}_br up sudo ip address add ${pub_addr_prefix}.${offset}/${pub_addr_mask} brd + dev ${pub_if_name}
deleted_lines: # if_name: Interface name on each host local if_name=$1 local offset=$2 local host_ip=$3 shift 3 sudo brctl addbr ${if_name}_br sudo ip link add gretap_$key type gretap local $host_ip remote $node key $key sudo ip link set gretap_$key up remote_command $node sudo -i ip link add ${if_name} type gretap local $node remote $host_ip key $key remote_command $node sudo -i ip link set ${if_name} up sudo brctl addif ${if_name}_br gretap_$key sudo ip link add ${if_name}_br_if type veth peer name ${if_name} sudo brctl addif ${if_name}_br ${if_name}_br_if sudo ip link set ${if_name}_br_if up sudo ip link set ${if_name} up sudo ip link set ${if_name}_br up

commit_message:
Refactor unit test code for disk pollsters

There are four test methods in tests/compute/pollsters/test_diskio.py
which looks very similar except the cache names are different.

This patch adds a class attribute named CACHE_KEY to reduce four methods
to one.

Change-Id: I269a10a5db3dcb43ae83e385bb6ae4468b0a9810

commit_message:
update plugin doc

After doing a couple of external plugins I found that basically things
don't work unless you enable_service in the settings file. Document
that as a requirement, and clean up the rest of the docs around the
external plugins to be consistent with that.

Change-Id: I13aee7dbf112ce9663e8338b555a208327f89b61
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/24/154224/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Your settings should include any ``enable_service`` lines required by your plugin. This is especially important if you are kicking off services using ``run_process`` as it only works with enabled services. looks like the extras.d dispatcher above. [[local|localrc]] enable_plugin ec2api git://git.openstack.org/stackforge/ec2api
deleted_lines: looks like the extras.d dispatcher above **except** it should not include the is_service_enabled conditional. All external plugins are always assumed to be enabled. enable_plugin glusterfs https://github.com/sdague/devstack-plugins glusterfs

Add vlan_transparent attribute to network model

attribute. Add this attribute to the network model.

commit_message:
Adds devref for API Microversions

As patches are being added which use the new microversions
framework, it will be useful to have some guidance for developers
on how to use it.

Partially implements blueprint api-microversions

Change-Id: I6a118388a436e6ea0a3fdcb998f7a7ba4fbf6e8f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/41/150641/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: API Microversions ================= Background ---------- Nova uses a framework we call 'API Microversions' for allowing changes to the API while preserving backward compatibility. The basic idea is that a user has to explicitly ask for their request to be treated with a particular version of the API, and if they do not ask they will get a stable version. So breaking changes can be added to the API without breaking users who don't specifically ask for it. This is done with an HTTP header ``X-OpenStack-Compute-API-Version`` which is a monotonically increasing semantic version number starting from ``2.1``. For full details please read the `Kilo spec for microversions <http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova-specs/tree/specs/kilo/approved/api-microversions.rst>`_ In Code ------- In ``nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py`` we define an @api_version decorator which is intended to be used on Controller methods. Some examples: A new API method ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ In the controller class:: @wsgi.Controller.api_version("2.4") def my_api_method: .... This method would only be available if the caller had specified an ``X-OpenStack-Compute-API-Version`` of >= 2.4. If they had specified a lower version (or not specified it and received the default of 2.1) the server would respond with HTTP/404. A method which changes its behaviour ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ In the controller class:: @wsgi.Controller.api_version("2.1", "2.4") def my_api_method: .... method_1 ... @wsgi.Controller.api_version("2.4") def my_api_method: .... method_2 ... If a caller specified 2.1, 2.2 or 2.3 (or received the default of 2.1) they would see the result from ``method_1``, 2.4 or later ``method_2``. It is vital that the two methods have the same name, so (currently) one of them will need ``#noqa`` to avoid failing flake8's F811 rule. The two methods may be different in any kind of semantics (schema validation, return values, response codes, etc) Other necessary changes ----------------------- If you are adding a patch which adds a new microversion, it is necessary to add changes to other places which describe your change: * ``REST_API_VERSION_HISTORY`` in ``nova/api/openstack/api_version_request.py`` * ``_MAX_API_VERSION`` in ``nova/api/openstack/api_version_request.py`` Testing Microversioned code --------------------------- TODO (gilliard): write this section :)

commit_message:
Nova Network for the Overcloud

Nova Network is a fully supported component of OpenStack with no
concrete plans or timeline for deprecation. It should be offered as an
option for the Overcloud network configuration. Neutron will remain the
default option in devtest.

Change-Id: Iec647bacf345e636a8f41ddb868d664eeb184cc9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/45/108145/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== Nova Network for the Overcloud ============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo-juno-overcloud-nova-network Nova Network is a fully supported component of OpenStack with no concrete plans or timeline for deprecation. It should be offered as an option for the Overcloud network configuration. Neutron will remain the default option in devtest. Problem Description =================== * Nova Network is a fully supported component of OpenStack, yet there is no support for it in a TripleO deployed Overcloud [#]_. * Operators may already be familiar with Nova Network due to its use in their existing production deployments. * Nova Network's multi-host mode offers a more distributed and fault tolerant network architecture over TripleO's existing overcloud network configuration. Proposed Change =============== We will offer Nova Network as a choice for network configuration of the Overcloud. We will offer Nova Network as a choice for network configuration of the Overcloud. In a devtest run, Nova Network will be chosen by setting an environment variable: export OVERCLOUD_USE_NOVA_NETWORK=1 We'll add a new nova-network element that installs the necessary services for Nova Network and exposes their needed configuration. We will support the 3 network managers: * FlatManager * FlatDhcpManager * VlanManager And Nova-Network's 2 operating modes: * Single-Host * Multi-Host Heat template changes will be needed to allow setting the chosen configuration for Nova Network. **TODO** Identify what areas of Nova Network will need to be made highly available and how those plans will fit into our existing HA architecture. It's possible that running Nova Network in Multi-Host mode is sufficient HA support for Nova Network. Alternatives ------------ * We could choose to not add support for all 3 network managers. FlatDhcpManager and VlanManaer are likely the most desirable. * We could not choose not to support Single-Host mode. The downside to this choice is that Single-Host mode is likely useful for smaller, development/test, or POC deployments. Security Impact --------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- Network configuration will be done with the nova client instead of the neutron client when using Nova Network. End users must be made aware of which client to use depending on how the Overcloud was configured. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Nova Network is typically very performant due to its lightweight implementation and use of Linux Bridges. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers will be able to choose Nova Network or Neutron for the Overcloud. They will be expected to supply the needed parameters to Heat templates based on the choice of network configuration. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: james-slagle Work Items ---------- * tripleo-image-elements * add elements for Nova Network for installation and configuration * update existing nova elements to not assume Neutron, particularly in the nova.conf template * tripleo-heat-templates * Heat template updates * tripleo-incubator * update devtest to add a Nova Network option for the Overcloud * update TripleO documentation for Nova Network option Dependencies ============ * This spec depends on Nova Network continuing to be a supported component of OpenStack. We may identify and need to fix bugs in Nova Network and will need the ability to have any such issues addressed. Testing ======= This change should be tested in TripleO CI. Assuming CI capacity allows, new Overcloud jobs will be added that use Nova Network instead of Neutron. Documentation Impact ==================== TripleO documentation will be updated to document the choice of Nova Network. References ========== .. [#] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-January/025824.html .. [#] http://docs.openstack.org/grizzly/openstack-compute/admin/content/existing-ha-networking-options.html

commit_message:
Use package-installs in nova elements

Updates the nova related elements to use the declarative package install
support provided by the package-installs element.

Change-Id: I31d15bd046e06eb53105223bc1c645968b496fc8

commit_message:
Change oslo.config to oslo_config

The oslo.config libraries are moving away from oslo-namespaced
packages.

Note that his requires oslo.config>=1.6.0

bp drop-namespace-packages

Change-Id: Ic0d4053875da0628f2359c109f2779d12aadc3eb

commit_message:
Removal of passive voice from chap 1, arch guide

Removal of passive voice from section_tech_considerations

Change-Id: I1db9d768bf50944d9aa987b7342fdb32a300bb98
Closes-bug: #1400550
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/48/153448/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>When designing a general purpose cloud, there is an implied requirement to ensure the design covers all of the following base services:</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para> Compute </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Network </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Storage </para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <para>Each of these services have different resource requirements. As a result, it is important to make design decisions relating directly to the service, as well as providing a balanced infrastructure that provides for all services.</para> <para>The mass of services, and the unique characteristics and requirements of each service, requiring design can impact the hardware selection process. Hardware designs are generated for each type of the following resource pools:</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para> Compute </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Network </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Storage </para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <para>Hardware decisions are also made in relation to network architecture and facilities planning. These factors play heavily into the overall architecture of an OpenStack cloud.</para> <title>Designing compute resources</title> <para>When designing compute resource pools, a number of factors will impact your design decisions. For example, decisions related to processors, memory, and storage within each hypervisor are just one element of designing compute resources. In addition, it is necessary to decide whether compute resources will be provided in a single pool or in multiple pools. We recommend the design of compute resources as pools of resources to be addressed on-demand.</para> <para>We recommend the design of more than one compute resource pool to best use the available resources of applications running in the cloud. Each independent resource pool should be designed to provide service for specific flavors of instances or groupings of flavors. Designing multiple resource pools helps to ensure that, as instances are resources will be allocated to make the most efficient use of available hardware. This is commonly referred to as bin packing.</para> <para>OpenStack is able configure the overcommit ratios—the ratio of virtual resources available for allocation overcommit ratio is 1.5:1. Determining the tuning of the overcommit ratios for both of these options during the design phase is important as it has a direct impact on the hardware layout of your compute nodes.</para> <para>For example, consider a m1.small instance uses 1 performance characteristics of different processors. Processors can include features specific to virtualized compute hosts including hardware assisted virtualization and technology related to memory paging (also known as EPT shadowing). These type of features can have a significant impact on the performance of your virtual machine running in the cloud.</para> <para>It is also important to consider the compute requirements of non-hypervisor nodes providing the following in the cloud:</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para> Controller </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Object storage </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Block storage </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> Networking services </para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <para>The number of processor cores and threads has a direct correlation to the cloud. Additional compute resource pools can be added to the cloud later, reducing the stress of unpredictability. In some cases, the demand on certain instance types or flavors may not justify individual hardware design. In either of these cases, initiate the design by allocating hardware designs that are capable of servicing the most common instances requests. If you are looking to add additional hardware designs to the overall architecture, this can be done at a later time.</para> </section> <title>Designing network resources</title> <para>OpenStack clouds traditionally have multiple network the cloud to both operators and tenants. The network services themselves also require network communication paths which should be separated from the other networks. When designing network services for a general purpose cloud, we recommend planning for a physical or logical separation of network segments that will be used by operators and tenants. We further suggest the creation of an additional network segment for access to internal services such as the message bus and databse used by the various cloud services. Segregating these services onto separate networks helps to protect sensitive data and protects against unauthorized access to services.</para> <para>Based on the requirements of instances being serviced in the cloud, the choice of network service will be the next decision that affects your design architecture.</para> <para>The choice between legacy networking (nova-network), as a (neutron), will have a huge impact on the architecture and design of the cloud <variablelist> <varlistentry> <term>Legacy networking (nova-network)</term> <listitem> <para>The legacy networking (nova-network) service is primarily a layer-2 networking service that functions in two modes. In legacy networking, the two modes differ in their use of VLANs. When using legacy networking in a flat network mode, all network hardware nodes and devices throughout the cloud are connected to a single layer-2 network segment that provides access to application data.</para> <para>When the network devices in the cloud support segmentation using VLANs, legacy networking can operate in the second mode. In this design model, each tenant within the cloud is assigned a network subnet which is mapped to a VLAN on the physical network. It is especially important to remember the maximum number of 4096 VLANs which can be used within a spanning tree domain. These limitations place hard limits on the amount of growth possible within the data center. When designing a general purpose cloud intended to support multiple tenants, we recommend the use of legacy networking with VLANs, and not in flat network mode.</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> </variablelist> <variablelist> <varlistentry> <term>OpenStack Networking (neutron)</term> <listitem> <para>OpenStack Networking (neutron) is a first class networking service that gives full control over creation of virtual network resources to tenants. This is often accomplished in the form of tunneling protocols which will establish encapsulated communication paths over existing network infrastructure in order to segment tenant traffic. These methods vary depending on the specific implementation, but some of the more common methods include tunneling over GRE, encapsulating with VXLAN, and VLAN tags.</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> </variablelist> clouds REST APIs by tenants and operators. Contrastingly, where redundancy of block storage volumes is more important we recommend making use of a redundant RAID configuration such as RAID 5 or performing flash storage solutions.</para> </section> <para>The software selection process plays a large role in the architecture of a general purpose cloud. deleted_lines: <para>When designing a general purpose cloud, there is an implied requirement to design for all of the base services generally associated with providing Infrastructure-as-a-Service: compute, network and storage. Each of these services have different resource requirements. As a result, it is important to make design decisions relating directly to the service currently under design, while providing a balanced infrastructure that provides for all services.</para> <para>When designing an OpenStack cloud as a general purpose cloud, the hardware selection process can be lengthy and involved due to the sheer mass of services which need to be designed and the unique characteristics and requirements of each service within the cloud. Hardware designs need to be generated for each type of resource pool; specifically, compute, network, and storage. In addition to the hardware designs, which affect the resource nodes themselves, there are also a number of additional hardware decisions to be made related to network architecture and facilities planning. These factors play heavily into the overall architecture of an OpenStack cloud.</para> <title>Designing compute resources</title> <para>We recommend you design compute resources as pools of resources which will be addressed on-demand. When designing compute resource pools, a number of factors impact your design decisions. For example, decisions related to processors, memory, and storage within each hypervisor are just one element of designing compute resources. In addition, it is necessary to decide whether compute resources will be provided in a single pool or in multiple pools.</para> <para>To design for the best use of available resources by applications running in the cloud, we recommend you design more than one compute resource pool. Each independent resource pool should be designed to provide service for specific flavors of instances or groupings of flavors. For the purpose of this book, "instance" refers to a virtual machine and the operating system running on the virtual machine. Designing multiple resource pools helps to ensure that, as instances are resources will be allocated in a way that makes the most efficient use of available hardware. This is commonly referred to as bin packing.</para> <para>OpenStack provides the ability to configure overcommit ratio—the ratio of virtual resources available for allocation overcommit ratio is 1.5:1. Determine the tuning of the overcommit ratios for both of these options during the design phase, as this has a direct impact on the hardware layout of your compute nodes.</para> <para>As an example, consider that a m1.small instance uses 1 performance characteristics of different processors. Some newly released processors include features specific to virtualized compute hosts including hardware assisted virtualization and technology related to memory paging (also known as EPT shadowing). These features have a tremendous positive impact on the performance of virtual machines running in the cloud.</para> <para>In addition to the impact on actual compute services, it is also important to consider the compute requirements of non-hypervisor nodes providing controller, object storage, block storage, or networking services in the cloud. The number of processor cores and threads has a direct correlation to the cloud, so it may be difficult to design for every specific use case in mind. Additional compute resource pools can be added to the cloud at a later time, so this unpredictability should not be a problem. In some cases, the demand on certain instance types or flavors may not justify an individual hardware design. In either of these cases, start by providing hardware designs which will be capable of servicing the most common instance requests first, looking to add additional hardware designs to the overall architecture in the form of new hardware node designs and resource pools as they become justified at a later time.</para></section> <title>Designing network resources</title> <para>An OpenStack cloud traditionally has multiple network the cloud to both operators and tenants. commit_message:
Deprecate LDAP Assignment Backend

Based upon feedback from the community, maintenance requirements and
discussions at the keystone midcycle, the LDAP Assignment backend is
being deprecated as of Kilo.

More information can be found on the OpenStack Development mailing list:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-January/055459.html

Change-Id: Ifc60f9f11f09d93de1f00d132465ea48524d0230
bp: deprecated-as-of-kilo

commit_message:
XenAPI: Use round-robin mirror for Ubuntu

ANL has discontinued their Ubuntu mirror.  Update the target
to be the official round-robin mirror which should be more stable long-term

Change-Id: I1271301d96a44888f45664537435e31dd38ff30d

commit_message:
gantt is a dead project, remove it

The gantt source trees are dead projects, we should remove them from
devstack.

Change-Id: I0f271891846d2ad7a7a8edd975cdfb4f08419f0c

commit_message:
remove tuskar

Tuskar server support is proposed as an external plugin here
I67dc8420582a40e18de7d5e00094bccc1184a7f9, we should remove Tuskar
from the main devstack tree.

then stop_tuskar fi fi # library code (equivalent to lib/tuskar) # --------- # - install_tuskarclient # - install_tuskar # - configure_tuskarclient # - configure_tuskar # - init_tuskar # - start_tuskar # - stop_tuskar # - cleanup_tuskar # Save trace setting XTRACE=$(set +o | grep xtrace) set +o xtrace # Defaults # -------- # tuskar repos TUSKAR_REPO=${TUSKAR_REPO:-${GIT_BASE}/openstack/tuskar.git} TUSKAR_BRANCH=${TUSKAR_BRANCH:-master} TUSKARCLIENT_REPO=${TUSKARCLIENT_REPO:-${GIT_BASE}/openstack/python-tuskarclient.git} TUSKARCLIENT_BRANCH=${TUSKARCLIENT_BRANCH:-master} # set up default directories TUSKAR_DIR=$DEST/tuskar TUSKARCLIENT_DIR=$DEST/python-tuskarclient TUSKAR_AUTH_CACHE_DIR=${TUSKAR_AUTH_CACHE_DIR:-/var/cache/tuskar} TUSKAR_STANDALONE=$(trueorfalse False TUSKAR_STANDALONE) TUSKAR_CONF_DIR=/etc/tuskar TUSKAR_CONF=$TUSKAR_CONF_DIR/tuskar.conf TUSKAR_API_HOST=${TUSKAR_API_HOST:-$HOST_IP} TUSKAR_API_PORT=${TUSKAR_API_PORT:-8585} # Tell Tempest this project is present TEMPEST_SERVICES+=,tuskar # Functions # --------- # Test if any Tuskar services are enabled # is_tuskar_enabled function is_tuskar_enabled { [[ ,${ENABLED_SERVICES} =~ ,"tuskar-" ]] && return 0 return 1 } # cleanup_tuskar() - Remove residual data files, anything left over from previous # runs that a clean run would need to clean up function cleanup_tuskar { sudo rm -rf $TUSKAR_AUTH_CACHE_DIR } # configure_tuskar() - Set config files, create data dirs, etc function configure_tuskar { setup_develop $TUSKAR_DIR if [[ ! -d $TUSKAR_CONF_DIR ]]; then sudo mkdir -p $TUSKAR_CONF_DIR fi sudo chown $STACK_USER $TUSKAR_CONF_DIR # remove old config files rm -f $TUSKAR_CONF_DIR/tuskar-*.conf TUSKAR_POLICY_FILE=$TUSKAR_CONF_DIR/policy.json cp $TUSKAR_DIR/etc/tuskar/policy.json $TUSKAR_POLICY_FILE cp $TUSKAR_DIR/etc/tuskar/tuskar.conf.sample $TUSKAR_CONF # common options iniset $TUSKAR_CONF database connection `database_connection_url tuskar` # logging iniset $TUSKAR_CONF DEFAULT debug $ENABLE_DEBUG_LOG_LEVEL iniset $TUSKAR_CONF DEFAULT use_syslog $SYSLOG if [ "$LOG_COLOR" == "True" ] && [ "$SYSLOG" == "False" ]; then # Add color to logging output setup_colorized_logging $TUSKAR_CONF DEFAULT tenant user fi configure_auth_token_middleware $TUSKAR_CONF tuskar $TUSKAR_AUTH_CACHE_DIR if is_ssl_enabled_service "key"; then iniset $TUSKAR_CONF clients_keystone ca_file $SSL_BUNDLE_FILE fi iniset $TUSKAR_CONF tuskar_api bind_port $TUSKAR_API_PORT } # init_tuskar() - Initialize database function init_tuskar { # (re)create tuskar database recreate_database tuskar tuskar-dbsync --config-file $TUSKAR_CONF create_tuskar_cache_dir } # create_tuskar_cache_dir() - Part of the init_tuskar() process function create_tuskar_cache_dir { # Create cache dirs sudo mkdir -p $TUSKAR_AUTH_CACHE_DIR sudo chown $STACK_USER $TUSKAR_AUTH_CACHE_DIR } # install_tuskarclient() - Collect source and prepare function install_tuskarclient { git_clone $TUSKARCLIENT_REPO $TUSKARCLIENT_DIR $TUSKARCLIENT_BRANCH setup_develop $TUSKARCLIENT_DIR } # configure_tuskarclient() - Set config files, create data dirs, etc function configure_tuskarclient { setup_develop $TUSKARCLIENT_DIR } # install_tuskar() - Collect source and prepare function install_tuskar { git_clone $TUSKAR_REPO $TUSKAR_DIR $TUSKAR_BRANCH } # start_tuskar() - Start running processes, including screen function start_tuskar { run_process tuskar-api "tuskar-api --config-file=$TUSKAR_CONF" } # stop_tuskar() - Stop running processes function stop_tuskar { # Kill the screen windows local serv for serv in tuskar-api; do stop_process $serv done } # create_tuskar_accounts() - Set up common required tuskar accounts function create_tuskar_accounts { # migrated from files/keystone_data.sh local service_tenant=$(openstack project list | awk "/ $SERVICE_TENANT_NAME / { print \$2 }") local admin_role=$(openstack role list | awk "/ admin / { print \$2 }") local tuskar_user=$(get_or_create_user "tuskar" "$SERVICE_PASSWORD") get_or_add_user_role $admin_role $tuskar_user $service_tenant if [[ "$KEYSTONE_CATALOG_BACKEND" = 'sql' ]]; then local tuskar_service=$(get_or_create_service "tuskar" \ "management" "Tuskar Management Service") get_or_create_endpoint $tuskar_service \ "$REGION_NAME" \ "$SERVICE_PROTOCOL://$TUSKAR_API_HOST:$TUSKAR_API_PORT" \ "$SERVICE_PROTOCOL://$TUSKAR_API_HOST:$TUSKAR_API_PORT" \ "$SERVICE_PROTOCOL://$TUSKAR_API_HOST:$TUSKAR_API_PORT" fi } # Restore xtrace $XTRACE # Tell emacs to use shell-script-mode ## Local variables: ## mode: shell-script ## End:

commit_message:
Correct XMLEquals matcher for ordering

The order of attributes in elements for generated XML will vary based
on the order of the keys in the dictionary which causes this matcher
to fail since it's assuming that the child elements can be ordered
just on the tag. This can be seen by setting the PYTHONHASHSEED value
to something other than 0.

With this fix, the XMLEquals matcher also uses the attribute names to
sort the child elements so that the matcher works with different
orderings.

Change-Id: I2875a10e77beaa1b491ac4fc579bcaada159c4fc
Partial-Bug: #1348818
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/18/138918/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _compare_elems(el1, el2): if el1.tag < el2.tag: return -1 if el1.tag > el2.tag: return 1 # Tags are the same, compare attrs. for a in set(list(el1.attrib) + list(el2.attrib)): a1 = el1.attrib.get(a) a2 = el2.attrib.get(a) if a1 is None: return 1 if a2 is None: return -1 if a1 < a2: return -1 if a1 > a2: return 1 # They're the same. return 0 def _sorted_children(doc): return sorted(doc.getchildren(), cmp=_compare_elems)
deleted_lines: def _sorted_children(doc): return sorted(doc.getchildren(), key=lambda el: el.tag)

commit_message:
Spec for volume statistics reporting

Specification for bp: volume-statistics-reporting

Change-Id: If5104749a155e819aa5df1eccbada4dbe753a40e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/90/105190/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Volume Statistics Reporting ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/volume-statistics-reporting For cloud deployers who are using different storage back-ends from different vendors, which can be usual for private clouds transformed from traditional enterprise IT environment, it'd be great if there is a unified mechanism to collect Cinder level volume statistics on a per volume basis. Problem description =================== Current Volume drivers mostly only reports scheduling-essential stats to scheduler, which isn't useful for the purpose of monitoring (billing). It'd be greate if there is a unified mechanism to collect Cinder level volume statistics on per volume basis. Per volume statistics can help mainly in following two area: * Monitor (collect, cosolidate and display) volumes from different vendors _within_ openstack. * Get the per volume statistics for the use of metering/billing (like AWS IOPS-provisioned EBS charging users based on how many IOs have been done). Although Celiometer + Nova (hypervisor level per block device statistics sent to Celiometer) can help monitoring/billing in-use volumes and is volume backend independent, but there are operations doesn't involve hypervisors (e.g. volume migration, retype) which deployers are also interested in having them monitored or even billed. Proposed change =============== Each volume driver (hopefully) reports volume statistics to volume manager, a minimum set of information includes: * Identifier (Backend name/Volume UUID); * Average Read IOPS; * Average Write IOPS; * Average Read Request Size (in bytes); * Average Write Request Size (in bytes); +-------------+---------------+-----------+---------------------+ | Identifier | Avg. R/W IOPS | Bandwidth | Avg. Request Size | +-------------+---------------+-----------+---------------------+ Such stats should include at least two level of information: back-end wide and per volume statistics. Here is an example of a backend named 'Example Storage Back' with 3 volumes: 'Example Storage Back',1120,210,3877,7997; 96331F4A-2E15-4CB0-8BC0-ADAA93BF3CEE,1000,200,4096,8192; 1427C04E-D8A1-4157-A201-28F2389C3F43,0,0,0,0; 70C6860C-8A08-45B4-9F0E-D3BB89F7D812,120,10,2048,4096; These stats will be captured every once in a while (default 60 seconds), and volume manager will send them via notification to aggregator like Celiometer. Alternatives ------------ As mentioned in 'Problem description', we are already able to capture statistics of 'in-use' (a.k.a attached) volumes with Celiometer + Nova. However, this combination can't handle detached volumes thus not able to provide statistics for operations like volume migration. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- This feature will add a new type of notification - 'volume.statistics'. Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ This feature adds another internal driver level API that might slightly increase the amount of traffic exchanged between Cinder volume service and storage backend, as well as notification traffic. The actual amount of increased traffic is linear with the total # of volumes, but given the stats for each volume is small in size (64 bytes is more than enough), the traffic increase is affordable/managable: * For 10,000 volumes, total traffic increase will be less than 64KB. * For 100,000 volumes, total trafic increase will be less than 640KB. Other deployer impact --------------------- Two new backend-level configuration options will be added to controll the frequency of detailed stats reporting or turning this feature on and off. * detailed_volume_stats_report_interval, default value 60 (secs) * detailed_volume_stats_report, default value True Deployer who wish to consume these detailed information will have to configure their monitoring/billing system to adopt the change. Developer impact ---------------- Driver developers shall implement the newly added get_detailed_volume_stats() call in their drivers. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: zhiteng-huang (winston-d on IRC) Work Items ---------- * volume manager change: calling driver.get_detailed_volume_stats() and then send out notification; * volume driver change: interact with storage backends to gather information and probably have to do some processing before returning formatted results to manager. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Once LVM driver detailed stats is available, new test cases can be added to Telemetry notification API tests. Documentation Impact ==================== Two new config options will be added, please check 'Other deployer impact' session. References ========== Juno design summit discussion etherpad for the topic: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/juno-cinder-framework-for-state-reporting

Currently, generic nfs driver (remotefs) already has a method
_create_qcow2_file, but there is not any related configuration in
cinder.conf to make the nfs driver to use this method.

The qcow2 format is already supported in glusterfs driver, we can

bluprint qcow2-on-generic-nfs-driver

Change-Id: I35a81bae9dc885a60d76999c044c260e0e2d658e
'}]
commit_message:
Add create qcow2 support in generic nfs driver

Currently, generic nfs driver (remotefs) already has a method
_create_qcow2_file, but there is not any related configuration in
cinder.conf to make the nfs driver to use this method.

The qcow2 format is already supported in glusterfs driver, we can
do this simlar to glusterfs.

bluprint qcow2-on-generic-nfs-driver

Change-Id: I35a81bae9dc885a60d76999c044c260e0e2d658e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/52/103752/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================= Add create qcow2 support in remotefs driver ================================================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/qcow2-on-generic-nfs-driver Problem description =================== Currently, generic nfs driver (remotefs) already has a method _create_qcow2_file, but there is not any related configuration in cinder.conf to make the nfs driver to use this method. The qcow2 format is already supported in glusterfs driver, we can do this simlar to glusterfs. Proposed change =============== Add a bool "nfs_qcow2_volumes" config to cinder.conf, with it set to True and "nfs_sparsed_volumes" set to False, volumes will be created as QCOW2 file rather than regular raw or sparse file. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <zhangleiqiang> Work Items ---------- To support this feature, the work items are: * Init "nfs_qcow2_volumes" config in cinder.volume.drivers.nfs * Create the corresponding format of volumes according the config in cinder.volume.drivers.nfs.RemoteFsDriver:_do_create_volume method Dependencies ============ [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/support-volume-backup-for-qcow2 [2] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/add-support-store-volume-format-info Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

subject: Title: Verifying Cinder quota usage
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-08 12:09:19.000000000', 'files': ['specs/VerifyingCinderQuotas.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs/commit/7f16ecedb8bfc2a0a57cdb8f8057fa67e0e96403', 'message': 'Title: Verifying Cinder quota usage

Cinder maintains a table called quota_usage in the Cinder db to record the number of volumes and their
sizes that are used by each tenant. This record is used for the quota verification of the tenant.
It is relatively slow to count all the volumes owned by the tenant, sum up the volume sizes and populate
this record in scale and there are chances that this record may not match with what the tenant is
actually using when there are coding errors in Cinder or there is constant create, update or delete of
volumes in the tenant.

I am proposing a tool or a script outside Cinder that counts all the volumes owned by each and every
tenant and also sums up their sizes to verify if the quota usage record for the respective tenant is
correct in the table.

Change-Id: I9553b7b33b3eb5fac72bfbe5a3087eed608415da
'}]
commit_message:
Title: Verifying Cinder quota usage

Cinder maintains a table called quota_usage in the Cinder db to record the number of volumes and their
sizes that are used by each tenant. This record is used for the quota verification of the tenant.
It is relatively slow to count all the volumes owned by the tenant, sum up the volume sizes and populate
this record in scale and there are chances that this record may not match with what the tenant is
actually using when there are coding errors in Cinder or there is constant create, update or delete of
volumes in the tenant.

I am proposing a tool or a script outside Cinder that counts all the volumes owned by each and every
tenant and also sums up their sizes to verify if the quota usage record for the respective tenant is
correct in the table.

Change-Id: I9553b7b33b3eb5fac72bfbe5a3087eed608415da
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/40/112840/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================================== Title: Verifying the Cinder Quota Usage ======================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/verifying-cinder-quota-usage Problem description =================== Cinder maintains a table called quota_usage in the Cinder db to record the number of volumes and their sizes that are used by each tenant. This record is used for the quota verification of the tenant. It is relatively slow to count all the volumes owned by the tenant, sum up the volume sizes and populate this record in scale and there are chances that this record may not match with what the tenant is actually using when there are coding errors in Cinder or there is constant create, update or delete of volumes in the tenant. Proposed change =============== We are suggesting a tool or a script outside Cinder that counts all the volumes owned by each and every tenant and also sums up their sizes to verify if the quota usage record for the respective tenant is correct in the table. Given that the script can find quota problems before the limit is hit it should make debugging much easier, especially in scale. Alternatives ------------ Why can't this be handled or fixed within Cinder. Yes, it can be fixed within Cinder but the reason it is seperate script is that, it is a resource heavy (particularly database) operation and should only be run by an admin aware of this fact. If this script is run as a routine in Cinder, then it would hog all the cinder resources and slow down all the Cinder service operations. Data Model impact ----------------- No data model change required. REST API impact --------------- 2 new REST APIs namely "quota_usage_verify" and "quota_usage_fix" have to be developed. Security impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? No, this script does not touch any of the sensitive data. * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? No, this script does not alter any REST API * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? No * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? No * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. Yes,this script will involve using the user-provided data for the number of volumes and the total size limit for all volumes put together from the quota point of view. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. No Notifications impact -------------------- No extra or changes to an existing notification required. Other end user impact --------------------- Aside from the API, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? Only the Admin user will run this script. There is no impact to other end user. * Does this change have an impact on python-cinderclient? What does the user interface there look like? No, there is no change or impact to python-cinderclient Performance Impact ------------------ The script will actually query the Cinder Database for getting the volume numbers and the quota numbers for the tenants. So, there might be performance impact in large scale deployments. There will not be any locking used by the script. Deployer impact --------------- I am proposing to deploy this script as part of cinder-manage Developer impact ----------------- There is no change to the driver API or core Cinder services and so there is no impact to the other developers. Implementation ============== The proposed script would read the volumes in use and their sizes for different tenants from the Volumes table in Cinder db and also read the hard limit or the quota numbers for the tenants from the quota_classes table in the Cinder db. With both the numbers, the script will calculate the quota usage and then validate it against the in use volumes and their sizes from the quota_usage table in the same Cinder db. This script will be implemented as quota_usage_verify and quota_usage_fix options under cinder-manage storage management with two sub options "--all" and "--tenant id" cinder-manage sm quota_usage_verify --all (all means all the tenants or projects) cinder-manage sm quota_usage_verify --tenant id (specifically for a tenant) cinder-manage sm quota_usage_fix --all (fix the quota usage mismatches for all the tenants) cinder-manage sm quota_usage_fix --tenant id (fix the quota usage mismatches for a specific tenant/project) Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee launchpad-id: maheshkumar.pandurangan@hp.com Other contributor launchpad-id: siva-subramaniam Work Items ---------- Script development - 1 week REST API Implementation and unit testing - 1 week CLI Implementation and unit testing - 1 week Tempest test development and run - 1 week Documentation- 1 week Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest tests will be added to test cinder quota usages which inturn will use the proposed APIs and CLIs Documentation Impact ==================== Proposed APIs and CLIs have to be documented as part of Cinder-Manage. References ========== https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1174193 http://blog.arxcruz.net/deleting-openstack-instances-directly-from-database

commit_message:
support deferred deletion for volumes

New feature aims to support deferred deletion for volumes to
avoid data loss by mistake.

blueprint volume-delete-protect

Change-Id: I0dc282564175e0ed674fb014ad1fc216f42b4490
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/34/97034/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== support deferred deletion for volumes ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/volume-delete-protect This blueprint aims to support deferred deletion for volumes to avoid data loss by mistake. Problem description =================== Currently in cinder, calling the API of deleting volume means the volume will be deleted immediately. If the user specify a wrong volume by mistake, the data in the volume may be lost forever. To avoid this, we hope to add a deferred deletion mechanism for volumes. So for a certain amount of time, volumes can be restored after the user find a misuse of the API about deleting volume. Proposed change =============== According to the config options, decide if support deferred deletion for volumes. If support deferred deletion, use "soft_delete" implements deleting volume. A new API function and corresponding cinder command will be added to restore soft-deleted volumes. Alternatives ------------ none Data model impact ----------------- none REST API impact --------------- Add a new REST API to restore volume: * POST v2/{tenant_id}/volumes/{volume_id}/action JSON request schema definition: { "restore": null } if success, return http return code 200. Security impact --------------- none Notifications impact -------------------- none Other end user impact --------------------- add a command line "cinder restore <volume-id>" in python-cinderclient. Performance Impact ------------------ none Other deployer impact --------------------- 1. Add a config option <reclaim_volume_interval>, means interval in seconds for reclaiming deleted volumes, i.e. After the user delete volume, at least in <reclaim_volume_interval> seconds, the volume will not be deleted, the user can restore the deleted volume. 2. Add a config option <destroy_soft_deleted_volumes_poll_interval>, means poll interval in seconds for a period task that check if soft-deleted volumes old enough, if yes, really delete them. Developer impact ---------------- none Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Zhou Yu <vitas.yuzhou@huawei.com> Work Items ---------- 1. Add a volume api called "soft_delete". 2. Modify current implement of deleting volume to support "soft_delete". 3. Add a period task to cleanup the soft-delete volumes which have expired, and support the config options <reclaim_volume_interval> and <destroy_soft_deleted_volumes_poll_interval>. 4. Add a REST API called "restore_volume". 5. Add a command line "cinder restore <volume-id>". Dependencies ============ none Testing ======= Unit tests as well. Documentation Impact ==================== The cinder client documentation will need to be updated to reflect the new command, i.e. cinder restore <volume-id>. The cinder API documentation will need to be updated to reflect the new REST API, i.e. restore volume REST API. The cinder configuration documentation will need to be updated to reflect the new two config options, i.e. <reclaim_volume_interval> and <destroy_soft_deleted_volumes_poll_interval> References ========== https://www.mail-archive.com/openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org/msg18522.html

commit_message:
VMware raw device cinder driver

OpenStack currently lacks support for attaching VMware raw devices
to Virtual machines. This blueprint adds the support in cinder
for managing volumes backed by VMware raw devices.

Change-Id: I125b22ad82e2ba30321a75016782af58e80ea8cf
Implements: blueprint vmware-raw-device-cinder-driver
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/85/128685/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================== VMware raw device cinder driver =============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/vmware-raw-device-cinder-driver https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vmware-raw-device In VMware, Raw Device Mapping(RDM) is a method to provide direct access to a LUN on a iscsi or fibre channel storage system for a virtual machine. OpenStack currently lacks support for attaching VMware raw devices to Virtual machines. This blueprint adds the support in cinder and a follow up blueprint against Nova's VMware driver will allow users to use these cinder volumes. Problem description =================== RDM is a mapping file in a separate VMFS volume that acts as a proxy for a raw physical storage device. The RDM allows a virtual machine to directly access and use the storage device. The RDM contains metadata for managing and redirecting disk access to the physical device. We need a new driver in cinder to allow manipulation of RDM volumes and expose them as cinder volumes. Proposed change =============== Add a cinder driver that will allow basic operations involving raw devices in VMware. Supported operations will be: * create volume * destroy volume * attach volume to an instance * detach volume from an instance In VMware, Raw Device Mapping can be used in virtual(rdm) and physical(rdmp) compatibility mode. Virtual mode specifies full virtualization of the mapped device, whereas the physical mode specifies minimal SCSI virtualization of the mapped device, allowing the greatest flexibility for SAN management software.The proposed driver will support both compatibility modes. Additionally, it can coexist with the current vmdk driver in VMware and can be enabled in the cinder.conf as follows: enabled_backends=vmware_block_device,vmware_vmdk VMware VCenter connectivity information and a list of available devices will be provided in cinder.conf Only these devices will be considered when a rdm/rdmp volume is created in cinder. They can be provided either as LUN UUIDs or as canonical names. Creating a RDM volume requires the following: * define a new volume type: cinder type-create rdm * define disk_type and disk_mode properties: cinder type-key rdm set vmware:disk_type=rdm cinder type-key rdm set vmware:disk_mode=persistent where disk_mode can be one of the following: persistent, independent_persistent, independent_nonpersistent, nonpersistent, undoable, append * associate the rdm type with the VMwareBlockDevice backend cinder type-key rdm set volume_backend_name=VMwareBlockDevice * create the volume cinder create --volume-type rdm --display-name rdm_volume 1 Creating a RDMP volume requires the following: * define a new volume type: cinder type-create rdmp * define disk_type property: cinder type-key rdmp set vmware:disk_type=rdmp * associate the rdmp type with the VMwareBlockDevice backend cinder type-key rdmp set volume_backend_name=VMwareBlockDevice * create the volume cinder create --volume-type rdmp --display-name rdm_volume 1 On volume create, the driver will check if a device with a given size amongst the list of available devices is available. The first time a volume is attached to a virtual machine using "nova volume-attach" an available device is selected and the volume is decorated with the LUN UUID of the selected device. When the volume is detached from a virtual machine, the LUN UUID will be preserved, so that the next attachment involving the volume will use the same device. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Following, a sample configuration section for the raw device driver is provided: [vmware_block_device] volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.vmware.rdm.VMwareBlockDeviceDriver vmware_wsdl_location=file:///opt/stack/vmware/vimService.wsdl vmware_host_password = passw0rd vmware_host_username = administrator vmware_host_ip = 192.168.1.0 volume_backend_name = VMwareBlockDevice vmware_available_devices = naa.6005076802818130ac0000000000065f, 02000600006005076802818130ac00000000000685323134352020 Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: mateescu <mateescu@ca.ibm.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * implement create_volume function in the VMwareBlockDeviceDriver cinder driver * implement delete_volume function in the VMwareBlockDeviceDriver cinder driver Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Continuous integration will be done for the VMware raw device cinder driver. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Add an admin API call to retreve scheduler state

Change-Id: I3c041b17c3c113d1b7f6191f2a2559141ec308ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/00/107700/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================== Cinder scheduler dump debug API =============================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/example There is currently no API for retreving the scheduler's view of the backends, which can be extremely useful when writing or debugging filters, volume types, backend configurations etc. Problem description =================== Admin has created a filter, weighter, type or backend configuration that isn't working as expected. Being able to view the scheduler's internal state is useful to be able to debug - things like incorrect field names, typos and similar are easy to spot. Proposed change =============== Adding an admin API call that returns the current state of backend from the scheduler as a JSON blob. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- A new call, with an optional scheduler host (for multi-scheduler deployments, defaulting to whichever scheduler happens to pick up the response) that returns a JSON blob. I can't sensibly design the schema until I've started wrting the code, so this section will be updated as the code gets prototyped. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ A blocking RPC in API context, like attach, can cause the API to consume many workers and so block new incoming requests if abused. The new call is intended as admin only, so this shouldn't be a significant issue, and it will be an extension so can be disabled in deployments where this is an unusually serious concern. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: duncan-thomas <duncan.thomas@gmail.com> Work Items ---------- * Write API extension. * Add call to python-cinderclient * Update API docs Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Might be possible to test on devstack, but difficult since every different backend will return different values Documentation Impact ==================== New API and client call needs to be documented References ========== None

commit_message:
Specify keystone SQL revocation driver

The default keystone configuration file included with most distributions
uses the deprecated 'keystone.contrib.revoke.backends.kvs' revocation
backend driver.  Use the keystone.contrib.revoke.backends.sql driver
instead.

Change-Id: I2c125fbd62346063f6cf2dd8ed71fcc85095f402
backport: juno
Closes-Bug: 1404969
(cherry picked from commit a407886259d6ae4b4087d7872d99554ce2278563)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/81/154081/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>In the <literal>[revoke]</literal> section, configure the SQL revocation driver:</para> <programlisting language="ini">[revoke] ... driver = keystone.contrib.revoke.backends.sql.Revoke</programlisting> </step> <step>

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-07-22 04:31:46.000000000', 'files': ['specs/juno/image-hidden.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs/commit/b8965fd83273eb80111d54a4c4b32f653edd8e0f', 'message': 'Add spec for: image-hidden

Add image hidden property to avoid image flooding.

Change-Id: I25391d5e7e44efd011588fb17ff1104a8eac7abe

commit_message:
Add spec for: image-hidden

Add image hidden property to avoid image flooding.

Change-Id: I25391d5e7e44efd011588fb17ff1104a8eac7abe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/74/108574/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================================================ Add image hidden property to avoid image flooding ================================================================ The goal of this spec is to adding a 'hidden' property to image so as to hide images when user don't want to list them. Problem description =================== Based on current implement, Glance doesn't allow to update the image data. As a result, user have to create a new image if there is any package update of the image OS. Then to keep the image be up-to-date, user will run into a image flooding issue. And from the end-user UX perspective, they will be hard to find the latest image version to boot instance. Proposed change =============== The proposal is trying to add a new property 'hidden' for image. By default, its value is 'False'. And the logic of image list will be improved to filter out the image with 'hidden'=True, unless there is a parameter 'show_hidden' pass in from REST API to display the hidden image explicitly. A typical user scenario may like this: 1. Cloud admin creates an image of Ubuntu 14.10. 2. There is an update for Ubuntu 14.10. 3. Cloud admin creates a new image with the latest Ubuntu 14.10. 4. Cloud admin update the old image with 'hidden'=True 5. End user won't see it by default, unless the 'show_hidden' parameter is enabled. 6. Existed instances created by old images won't be impacted. Alternatives ------------ We could also specify a property or tag to indicate if the image is hidden or not. The property can be predefined in glance-api.conf. But obviously, it may introduce more deployment work and causing the different behavior for different image service deployment. Data model impact ----------------- A new boolean field named 'hidden' will be added into [images] table as metadata. Its default value is False. REST API impact --------------- * GET:/v2/images?show_hidden=True * Description: Returns a subset of the larger collection of images and a link that you can use to get the next set of images, with the 'show_hidden' parameter, all images with 'hidden'=True won't be displayed if the show_hidden=False. By default, the 'hidden' images won't be displayed. * Method: GET * Normal response code(s): 200 * URL for the resource: /v2/images * Parameters which can be passed via the url show_hidden, Boolean, If show the hidden image or not. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- This feature needs a database migration to add a new field 'hidden' for [images] table. But it won't impact any existed fields and their value. By default, the value of 'hidden' is False. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: flwang Other contributors: markwash Work Items ---------- - Add 'hidden' field for image table and migration support - Add 'show_hidden' parameter support for REST API - Add 'show_hidden' support for Glance client Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Need to add unit test to cover this. Documentation Impact ==================== Please refer Other deployer impact. References ========== None

commit_message:
base angular-based launch instance wizard

This patch sets up a base launch instance wizard. It can server two
purposes:

* as a demo to show how to use wizard widget.
* enabling development for steps in the launch instance workflow.

Partially implements: blueprint launch-instance-redesign

Change-Id: I2519473343d6b8404cf4570ab451405c0034b686

commit_message:
Fix rspec installs during image builds

This change is adapted from Ief25f224fbe15530a503f7c53acef8759df281b4
to fix rspec installs when puppet runs during old school nodepool
snapshot builds.

Note we are not updating DIB and snapshot together because we do not yet
use DIB builds for the bare-* $THIN=false builds.

Change-Id: I4d0ab20d437da0c779bddc286664f9def98484e1

commit_message:
Provides VIF plugging for the instances

This change set provides the VIF plugging for virtual machines.

Currently impacted because neutron networks are not passing back the
VLAN unlike their nova network counterparts.  A separate bug will be
filed to Nova for this.

Change-Id: I8d86b7578a0868556d83299d8758781618aa7e3b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/31/154231/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from pypowervm.jobs import cnafrom pypowervm.wrappers import client_network_adapter as pvm_cnadef get_cnas(adapter, instance, host_uuid): """Returns the current CNAs on the instance. The Client Network Adapters are the Ethernet adapters for a VM. :param adapter: The pypowervm adapter. :param instance: The nova instance. :param host_uuid: The host system UUID. :returns The ClientNetworkAdapter wrappers that represent the CNAs on the VM. """ cna_resp = adapter.read(pvm_lpar.LPAR_ROOT, root_id=get_pvm_uuid(instance), child_type=pvm_cna.VADPT_ROOT) return pvm_cna.ClientNetworkAdapter.load_from_response(cna_resp) def crt_vif(adapter, instance, host_uuid, vif): """Will create a Client Network Adapter on the system. :param adapter: The pypowervm adapter API interface. :param instance: The nova instance to create the VIF against. :param host_uuid: The host system UUID. :param vif: The nova VIF that describes the ethernet interface. """ lpar_uuid = get_pvm_uuid(instance) # CNA's require a VLAN. If the network doesn't provide, default to 1 vlan = vif['network'].get('vlan', 1) cna.crt_cna(adapter, host_uuid, lpar_uuid, vlan, mac_addr=vif['address'])

commit_message:
Adds support for multiple tempest sources

Will now create "tempest-base" dir for each remote source.
On repo creation, will search existing directories for matching remote. If none
exits, will create a new directory

old:

 _ .rally/tempest
 |_base -> clone from source to here
 |_ ...for-deployment-<UUID1> -> copy from tempest base
 |_ ...for-deployment-<UUID2> -> copy from tempest base

new:

 _ .rally/tempest
 |_base
 ||_ tempest_base-<rand suffix specific for source> -> clone from source
 ||                                                    to here
 ||_ tempest_base-<rand suffix 2>
 |_ ...for-deployment-<UUID1> -> copy from relevant tempest_base
 |_ ...for-deployment-<UUID2> -> copy from relevant tempest_base

Change-Id: Ib9e697a2553c3e412892722653a817c3f83b481f

commit_message:
fallback to online validation if offline validation fails

Authmiddleware should fallback to purely online validation when
fetching certificate config failed or fetching revocation list failed.

Change-Id: I532e667cc26bbeb9bbd03605b9fb7ea7ebf14afa
Closes-Bug: #1384898

commit_message:
Remove custom string truth handling

Testing the delay_auth_decision for truth values is no longer necessary
as we do _conf_value_types_convert to convert paste string values into
those expected by the oslo.config options.

Change-Id: Ifa8be05830923a831a319bf291b7647ba0bbe781

commit_message:
Change oslo.messaging to oslo_messaging

The oslo libraries are moving away from namespace packages.

A hacking check is added to enforce use of the new location.

bp drop-namespace-packages

Change-Id: Ic96f3273284c6197d9f8aecdc49cbdca42886385

commit_message:
Extract preserve ephemeral on rebuild from servers plugin

The preserve ephemeral on rebuild functionality was merged into the servers plugin
code. This should never have happened and the hook for handling extra parameters
for the rebuild api used instead (otherwise we end up with monster functions).

This patch splits the relevant bits out to their own plugin.

Partially implements bp v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I0f35f897b9470039d509a97e6513c6cc806169b4

commit_message:
Fixes Hyper-V configdrive network injection issue

The Hyper-V driver is not properly handling static IP configuration
injection when flat_injected is true and networks don't have DHCP
enabled. This commit fixes the issue.

Change-Id: Ie54f1c892f1db53b1807661acacbae5bd45c0777
Closes-Bug: #1400069

commit_message:
Change oslo.serialization to oslo_serialization

The oslo libraries are moving away from namespace packages.

A hacking check is added to enforce use of the new location.

bp drop-namespace-packages

Change-Id: I76dc9f733b222144f0274f8854877587c3501d1e

commit_message:
Stop installing tempest

We run tempest inside of tox so no nee to install it. By not installing
it we decouple one more thing from the requirements sync.

Without this patch, due to branchless tempest, tempest must work with
master and all stable branch global requirements.

Although installing tempest should work on master, don't install it
anyway to make the user experience more uniform across master and
stable branches.

Note: Long term we can install this inside of a virtualenv
(I92648fffc1ad6af53006a0970722fd15f4e79dc2) but that logic hasn't landed
yet and installing tempest is breaking us. So leave moving this to a
virtualenv for a later patch.

Change-Id: I78d51f04ed01da4ce8aa0e127be028f969d3b4f8

commit_message:
Fix congress devstack keystone integration and keystone tempest test

Keystone does not return the tenantId column if there is no tenantId in the
backend. This patch updates the keystone user test to only check for the
tenantId value if present. This is a behavior that changed in keystone that
requires us to update this test.

Change-Id: I0ebaabdfd4b0284f1ddf1391fcae67b8cb4d4a55

commit_message:
Support for ext4 as default for ephemeral disks

Currently, ext4 is supported as default for all Linux.
Also, for non-linux and non-windows OSs the default is vfat
(used to be ext3).

There is still support for ext3 as the default if some
deployers do choose to keep that as the default, by using either
virt_mkfs or default_ephemeral_format configuration option.

Change-Id: I1b315043d0738bc4eec6739ad82be52e395f8d58
Closes-Bug: #1415407

However, it still supports the <filename>ext3</filename> file system, if it is required for some deployment purposes. The latter can be kept as the default file system type by specifying the corresponding value of either <parameter>virt_mkfs</parameter> or <parameter>default_ephemeral_format</parameter> configuration options.</para> </note> <procedure> <step><para>Persistent volume</para></step></procedure> <para>It represents a persistent virtualized block device independent of any particular instance.</para> <para>Persistent volume is created by a user, and its size is limited only by a user's quota and availability limits. Upon initial creation, a volume is a raw block device without a partition table or a file system. To partition or format a volume, you must attach it to an instance. Once they are attached to an instance, you can use persistent volumes in much the same way as you would use external hard disk drive. You can attach volumes to only one instance at a time, although you can detach and reattach volumes to as many different instances as you like.</para> <para>You can configure persistent volumes as bootable and use them to provide a persistent virtual instance similar to traditional non-cloud-based virtualization systems. commit_message:
Use proper capitalization for OVS table names

ovs-vsctl will convert the names for you, but native OVSDB won't.
It's always better to match case correctly when possible.

Partially-implemnts: blueprint vsctl-to-ovsdb
Change-Id: Ic782856446449a0296564cb6a0e6cf20d7ccfa7d

commit_message:
Fixes inline edit icon size/placement

- Adds the 'fa-fw' class to the check/times icons in editable table cells
This ensures matching widths
- Pads 'table_cell_wrapper' to ensure pencil icon is not over data
- Small tidy of surrounding code for readability

Change-Id: Ia8493d7578f8d393bc6054ac4da82187b008444c
Closes-bug: 1398928

commit_message:
Adds styling of "Confirm Password" Field in user forms

This patch adds the styling on the "Confirm Password" error message
shown when user enters different confirmation password.

Change-Id: If6dc9ec38979eef48e58d4f1b1ce157056e267e0
Closes-bug: #1418871

added_lines: def handle_delete(self): class PoolDeleteProgress(object): def __init__(self, val=False): self.pool = {'delete_called': val, 'deleted': val} self.vip = {'delete_called': val, 'deleted': val} if not self.resource_id: progress = PoolDeleteProgress(True) return progress progress = PoolDeleteProgress() if not self.metadata_get(): progress.vip['delete_called'] = True progress.vip['deleted'] = True return progress def _delete_vip(self): return self._not_found_in_call( self.neutron().delete_vip, self.metadata_get()['vip']) def _check_vip_deleted(self): return self._not_found_in_call( self.neutron().show_vip, self.metadata_get()['vip']) def _delete_pool(self): return self._not_found_in_call( self.neutron().delete_pool, self.resource_id) def check_delete_complete(self, prg): if not prg.vip['delete_called']: prg.vip['deleted'] = self._delete_vip() prg.vip['delete_called'] = True while not prg.vip['deleted']: prg.vip['deleted'] = self._check_vip_deleted() return False if not prg.pool['delete_called']: prg.pool['deleted'] = self._delete_pool() prg.pool['delete_called'] = True return prg.pool['deleted'] while not prg.pool['deleted']: prg.pool['deleted'] = super(Pool, self).check_delete_complete(True) return False
deleted_lines: from heat.engine import scheduler def _confirm_vip_delete(self): client = self.neutron() while True: try: yield client.show_vip(self.metadata_get()['vip']) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) break def _confirm_delete(self): while True: try: yield self._show_resource() except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) return def handle_delete(self): checkers = [] if self.metadata_get(): try: self.neutron().delete_vip(self.metadata_get()['vip']) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) else: checkers.append(scheduler.TaskRunner(self._confirm_vip_delete)) try: self.neutron().delete_pool(self.resource_id) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) else: checkers.append(scheduler.TaskRunner(self._confirm_delete)) return checkers def check_delete_complete(self, checkers): '''Push all checkers to completion in list order.''' for checker in checkers: if not checker.started(): checker.start() if not checker.step(): return False
