commit_message:
HP 3PAR Driver for Manila

Implement share driver for HP 3PAR arrays with File Persona capabilities.

NFS and CIFS shares can be created and deleted.
Snapshots can be created and deleted.
Read-only shares can be created from snapshots.

Does not support handling of share servers.

A pre-assigned IP address and a pre-configured VFS is used
instead of share networks.  This is done by setting 'hp3par_share_ip_address'
to the desired IP address in the manila.conf.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I90e19a1d34d568eba6178ca3dbb605f37c598439
Implements: blueprint hp3par-manila-driver
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/50/139850/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Hewlett Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """HP 3PAR Mediator for OpenStack Manila. This 'mediator' de-couples the 3PAR focused client from the OpenStack focused driver. """ from manila import exception from manila.i18n import _ from manila.i18n import _LI from manila.openstack.common import log as logging from oslo.utils import importutils import six hp3parclient = importutils.try_import("hp3parclient") if hp3parclient: from hp3parclient import client LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) DENY = '-' ALLOW = '+' class HP3ParMediator(object): def __init__(self, **kwargs): self.hp3par_username = kwargs.get('hp3par_username') self.hp3par_password = kwargs.get('hp3par_password') self.hp3par_api_url = kwargs.get('hp3par_api_url') self.hp3par_debug = kwargs.get('hp3par_debug') self.san_ip = kwargs.get('san_ip') self.san_login = kwargs.get('san_login') self.san_password = kwargs.get('san_password') self.san_ssh_port = kwargs.get('san_ssh_port') self.ssh_conn_timeout = kwargs.get('ssh_conn_timeout') self.san_private_key = kwargs.get('san_private_key') self._client = None def do_setup(self): if hp3parclient is None: msg = _('You must install hp3parclient before using the 3PAR ' 'driver.') LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.HP3ParInvalidClient(message=msg) try: self._client = client.HP3ParFilePersonaClient(self.hp3par_api_url) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to connect to HP 3PAR File Persona Client: %s') % six.text_type(e)) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message=msg) try: ssh_kwargs = {} if self.san_ssh_port: ssh_kwargs['port'] = self.san_ssh_port if self.ssh_conn_timeout: ssh_kwargs['conn_timeout'] = self.ssh_conn_timeout if self.san_private_key: ssh_kwargs['privatekey'] = self.san_private_key self._client.setSSHOptions( self.san_ip, self.san_login, self.san_password, **ssh_kwargs ) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to set SSH options for HP 3PAR File Persona ' 'Client: %s') % six.text_type(e)) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message=msg) if self.hp3par_debug: self._client.ssh.set_debug_flag(True) def get_capacity(self, fpg): try: result = self._client.getfpg(fpg) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to get capacity for fpg %s'), fpg) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message=msg) if result['total'] != 1: msg = (_('Failed to get capacity for fpg %s.'), fpg) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message=msg) else: KiB2GiB = 1024 * 1024 member = result['members'][0] total_capacity_gb = int(member['capacityKiB']) / KiB2GiB free_capacity_gb = int(member['availCapacityKiB']) / KiB2GiB return { 'total_capacity_gb': total_capacity_gb, 'free_capacity_gb': free_capacity_gb } def setup_server(self, ip, subnet, vlantag, fpg, vfs): try: result = self._client.createfsip(ip, subnet, fpg, vfs, vlantag=str(vlantag)) LOG.debug("createfsip result: %s", result) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to setup server for %s'), ip) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message=msg) @staticmethod def convert_protocol(share_proto): protocol = share_proto.lower() if protocol == 'cifs': protocol = 'smb' if protocol not in ['smb', 'nfs']: message = (_('Invalid protocol. Expected nfs or smb. Got %s.') % protocol) LOG.error(message) raise exception.InvalidInput(message) return protocol def create_share(self, share_name, share_proto, fpg, vfs, size): """Create the share and return its path.""" protocol = self.convert_protocol(share_proto) fstore = share_name try: result = self._client.createfstore( vfs, fstore, fpg=fpg, comment='OpenStack Manila fstore') LOG.debug("createfstore result=%s", result) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to create fstore %s'), fstore) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) try: size_str = str(size) result = self._client.setfsquota( vfs, fpg=fpg, fstore=fstore, scapacity=size_str, hcapacity=size_str) LOG.debug("setfsquota result=%s", result) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to setfsquota on %s'), fstore) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) try: result = self._client.createfshare( protocol, vfs, share_name, fpg=fpg, fstore=fstore, options='rw,no_root_squash,insecure', comment='OpenStack Manila fshare') LOG.debug("createfshare result=%s", result) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to create share %s') % share_name) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) try: result = self._client.getfshare( protocol, share_name, fpg=fpg, vfs=vfs, fstore=fstore) LOG.debug("getfshare result=%s", result) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to get fshare %s after creating it.'), share_name) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) if result['total'] != 1: msg = (_('Failed to get fshare %(share_name)s after creating it. ' 'Expected to get 1 fshare. Got %(total)s.'), {'share_name': share_name, 'total': result['total']}) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) if protocol == 'nfs': return result['members'][0]['sharePath'] else: return result['members'][0]['shareName'] def delete_share(self, share_name, share_proto, fpg, vfs): protocol = self.convert_protocol(share_proto) fstore = share_name try: self._client.removefshare(protocol, vfs, share_name, fpg=fpg, fstore=fstore) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to remove share %s') % share_name) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message=msg) try: self._client.removefstore(vfs, fstore, fpg=fpg) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to remove fstore %s'), fstore) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message=msg) def get_fpg(self, fpg): """Get the FPG by name or raise an exception.""" try: result = self._client.getfpg(fpg) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Exception during getfpg %s') % fpg) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) if not result['total'] == 1: message = (_('Error getting FPG (%(fpg)s): %(msg)s') % {'fpg': fpg, 'msg': result['message']}) LOG.error(message) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message) return result['members'][0] def get_vfs_name(self, fpg): return self.get_vfs(fpg)['vfsname'] def get_vfs(self, fpg, vfs=None): """Get the VFS or raise an exception.""" try: result = self._client.getvfs(fpg=fpg, vfs=vfs) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Exception during getvfs %s') % vfs) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) if result['total'] != 1: error_msg = result.get('message') if error_msg: message = (_('Error while validating FPG/VFS ' '(%(fpg)s/%(vfs)s): %(msg)s') % {'fpg': fpg, 'vfs': vfs, 'msg': result['message']}) LOG.error(message) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message) else: message = (_('Error while validating FPG/VFS ' '(%(fpg)s/%(vfs)s): Expected 1, ' 'got %(total)s.') % {'fpg': fpg, 'vfs': vfs, 'total': result['total']}) LOG.error(message) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message) return result['members'][0] def get_fsips(self, fpg, vfs): """Get the FSIPs for this FPG/VFS.""" try: result = self._client.getfsip(vfs, fpg=fpg) except Exception as e: msg = (_('Exception during getvfs: %s') % six.text_type(e)) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) if result['message'] is not None: message = (_('Error while getting FSIPs for FPG/VFS ' '(%(fpg)s/%(vfs)s): %(msg)s') % {'fpg': fpg, 'vfs': vfs, 'msg': result['message']}) LOG.error(message) raise exception.ShareBackendException(message) return result['members'] def create_snapshot(self, fstore, snapshot_tag, fpg, vfs): """Creates a snapshot of a share.""" try: result = self._client.createfsnap( vfs, fstore, snapshot_tag, fpg=fpg) LOG.debug("createfsnap result=%s", result) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to create snapshot for FPG/VFS/fstore ' '%(fpg)s/%(vfs)s/%(fstore)s') % {'fpg': fpg, 'vfs': vfs, 'fstore': fstore}) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) def delete_snapshot(self, fstore, snapshot_tag, fpg, vfs): """Deletes a snapshot of a share.""" try: pattern = '*_%s' % snapshot_tag result = self._client.getfsnap( pattern, fpg=fpg, vfs=vfs, fstore=fstore, pat=True) LOG.debug("getfsnap result=%s", result) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to get snapshot for FPG/VFS/fstore/tag ' '%(fpg)s/%(vfs)s/%(fstore)s/%(tag)s') % {'fpg': fpg, 'vfs': vfs, 'fstore': fstore, 'tag': snapshot_tag}) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) if result['total'] == 0: msg = (_LI('Found zero snapshots for FPG/VFS/fstore/tag ' '%(fpg)s/%(vfs)s/%(fstore)s/%(tag)s') % {'fpg': fpg, 'vfs': vfs, 'fstore': fstore, 'tag': snapshot_tag}) LOG.info(msg) return for member in result['members']: try: snapname = member['snapName'] result = self._client.removefsnap( vfs, fstore, snapname=snapname, fpg=fpg) LOG.debug("removefsnap result=%s", result) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to delete snapshot for FPG/VFS/fstore ' '%(fpg)s/%(vfs)s/%(fstore)s') % {'fpg': fpg, 'vfs': vfs, 'fstore': fstore}) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) # Need to reclaim the space, for the remove to be complete try: self._client.startfsnapclean(fpg, reclaimStrategy='maxspeed') except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Unexpected exception calling startfsnapclean for FPG ' '%s') % fpg) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) @staticmethod def validate_access_type(protocol, access_type): if access_type not in ('ip', 'user'): msg = (_("Invalid access type. Expected 'ip' or 'user'. " "Actual '%s'") % access_type) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.InvalidInput(msg) if protocol == 'nfs' and access_type != 'ip': msg = (_("Invalid NFS access type. HP 3PAR NFS supports 'ip'. " "Actual '%s'") % access_type) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.HP3ParInvalid(msg) return protocol def _change_access(self, plus_or_minus, share_name, share_proto, access_type, access_to, fpg, vfs): """Allow or deny access to a share. Plus_or_minus character indicates add to allow list (+) or remove from allow list (-). """ protocol = self.convert_protocol(share_proto) self.validate_access_type(protocol, access_type) try: if protocol == 'nfs': result = self._client.setfshare( protocol, vfs, share_name, fpg=fpg, fstore=share_name, clientip='%s%s' % (plus_or_minus, access_to)) else: # CIFS/SMB if access_type == 'ip': result = self._client.setfshare( protocol, vfs, share_name, fpg=fpg, fstore=share_name, allowip='%s%s' % (plus_or_minus, access_to)) else: perm = '%s%s:fullcontrol' % (plus_or_minus, access_to) result = self._client.setfshare(protocol, vfs, share_name, fpg=fpg, fstore=share_name, allowperm=perm) LOG.debug("setfshare result=%s", result) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(e) msg = (_('Failed to change (%(change)s) access to FPG/share ' '%(fpg)s/%(share)s to %(type)s %(to)s)') % {'change': plus_or_minus, 'fpg': fpg, 'share': share_name, 'type': access_type, 'to': access_to}) LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.ShareBackendException(msg) def allow_access(self, share_name, share_proto, access_type, access_to, fpg, vfs): """Grant access to a share.""" self._change_access(ALLOW, share_name, share_proto, access_type, access_to, fpg, vfs) def deny_access(self, share_name, share_proto, access_type, access_to, fpg, vfs): """Deny access to a share.""" self._change_access(DENY, share_name, share_proto, access_type, access_to, fpg, vfs)

commit_message:
Prevent CoreOS from using configdrive in ramdisk

Without this change, coreos-cloudinit will read and try to perform init
actions while we're provisioning. Under no circumstances (especially in
things like cleaning), do we want any contents of the disk to modify
ramdisk behavior.

Masking these units removes them at boot before it has an opportunity
to run.

Change-Id: Icd93954f0e4a76a7285d2914b9626b03fd457b9d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/46/153646/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
add conntrack-tool to manage security group

this patch introduce conntrack-tool to manage security
group. when a security group rule is deleted, it should
use conntrack-tool to delete the invalid ip connectivity.

Change-Id: I83ded140b37a4d276ab64911d73d4224b598c33b
Partially-Implements: bp conntrack-in-security-group
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/78/146778/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: security_groups = kwargs.get('security_groups', {}) "rule updated %r"), security_groups.keys()) if isinstance(security_groups, dict): for sg_rule in security_groups.values(): if sg_rule.get('action') == 'delete': self.firewall.update_defer_sg_rule( devices, sg_rule['rule'])

subject: Enhance iSCSI multipath support
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-15 00:54:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/6602a587fcc557cd3c5b7c946a2f16eb7e00baf6', 'message': 'Support multipath to iSCSI portal

Currently, data path to iSCSI volumes supports multipath via Nova's
control. However, if the primary iSCSI portal address becomes
unaccessible due to network failure, Nova-compute will fail to
attach or detach volumes even if another address for the portal is
online.

To avoid this issue, this patch adds an optional parameters
'target_portal_secondary', 'target_iqn_secondary', and
'target_lun_secondary' in 'connection_info' returned by
'os-initialize_connection' volume action API, which represent
a list of secondary addresses of the iSCSI portal and corresponding
lists of iqns and luns. For example:

  {"driver_volume_type": "iscsi",
   "data": {"target_portal": "10.0.2.15:3260",
            "target_iqn": "iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-01",
            "target_lun": 1,
            "target_portal_secondary": ["10.0.3.15:3260"],
            "target_iqn_secondary": ["iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-02"],
            "target_lun_secondary": [2],
            ...}}

This also modify brick/iscsi/connector.py to make the parameter
recognized and to login to every target.

In addition, this adds an config option 'iscsi_ip_address_secondary'
to specify a list of secondary portal addresses for LVM iSCSI Driver.

Change-Id: I2a650c8ae70189b738937eaea7e5cd28f896257c
Implements: blueprint iscsi-portal-multipath

Implements: blueprint iscsi-portal-multipath
'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2014-11-26 20:51:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/c19cc27248783a9587abda69526ceca8a437e374', 'message': 'Enhance iSCSI multipath support

Currently, nova-compute supports multipath for iSCSI volume data
path. It depends on response to targets discovery of from the main
iSCSI portal, expecting multiple portal addresses are contained.

However, some arrays only respond to discovery with a single portal
address, even if secondary portals are available. In this case,
nova-compute cannot know secondary portals and corresponding iSCSI
target IQN, so nova-compute cannot establish multiple sessions for
the target(s). To enable nova-compute to login to secondary portals,
cinder should tell all the portal addresses and corresponding
target iqns/luns.

With this patch initialize_connection API will return connection_info
with multiple portal addresses/iqns/luns when multipath=True is
specified in the connector info. For example:

  {"driver_volume_type": "iscsi",
   "data": {"target_portals": ["10.0.2.15:3260", "10.0.3.15:3260"],
            "target_iqns": ["iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-01",
                            "iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-02"],
            "target_luns": [1, 2],
            ...}}

This also modify brick/iscsi/connector.py to make the parameter
recognized and to login to every target.

In addition, this adds an config option
'iscsi_secondary_ip_addresses' to specify a list of secondary
portal addresses for LVM iSCSI Driver.

Change-Id: I2a650c8ae70189b738937eaea7e5cd28f896257c
Implements: blueprint iscsi-multipath-enhancement
'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-12-04 17:01:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/0e03c57538ee3aea5c3b3fbc4185b9c20b17c936', 'message': 'Enhance iSCSI multipath support

'}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2014-12-08 17:48:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/68ec993e0c4020a6d2391862361889d1452a9689', 'message': 'Enhance iSCSI multipath support

Currently, nova-compute supports multipath for iSCSI volume data
path. It depends on response to targets discovery of from the main
iSCSI portal, expecting multiple portal addresses are contained.

However, some arrays only respond to discovery with a single portal
address, even if secondary portals are available. In this case,
nova-compute cannot know secondary portals and corresponding iSCSI
target IQN, so nova-compute cannot establish multiple sessions for
the target(s). To enable nova-compute to login to secondary portals,
cinder should tell all the portal addresses and corresponding
target iqns/luns.

With this patch initialize_connection API will return connection_info
with multiple portal addresses/iqns/luns when multipath=True is
specified in the connector info. For example:

  {"driver_volume_type": "iscsi",
   "data": {"target_portals": ["10.0.2.15:3260", "10.0.3.15:3260"],
            "target_iqns": ["iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-01",
                            "iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-02"],
            "target_luns": [1, 2],
            ...}}

This also modify brick/iscsi/connector.py to make the parameter
recognized and to login to every target.

In addition, this adds an config option
'iscsi_secondary_ip_addresses' to specify a list of secondary
portal addresses for LVM iSCSI Driver.

Change-Id: I2a650c8ae70189b738937eaea7e5cd28f896257c
Implements: blueprint iscsi-multipath-enhancement

commit_message:
Enhance iSCSI multipath support

Currently, nova-compute and brick support multipath for iSCSI volume
data path. It depends on response to targets discovery of the main
iSCSI portal, expecting multiple portal addresses to be contained.

However, some arrays only respond to discovery with a single portal
address, even if secondary portals are available. In this case,
the connector cannot know secondary portals and corresponding
iSCSI target IQN, so cannot establish multiple sessions for
the target(s). To enable the connector to login to secondary portals,
cinder should tell all the portal addresses and corresponding
target iqns/luns.

With this patch initialize_connection API will return connection_info
with multiple portal addresses/iqns/luns when multipath=True is
specified in the connector info. For example:

  {"driver_volume_type": "iscsi",
   "data": {"target_portals": ["10.0.2.15:3260", "10.0.3.15:3260"],
            "target_iqns": ["iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-01",
                            "iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-02"],
            "target_luns": [1, 2],
            ...}}

This also modify brick/iscsi/connector.py to make the parameter
recognized and to login to every target.

In addition, this adds an config option
'iscsi_secondary_ip_addresses' to specify a list of secondary
portal addresses for LVM iSCSI Driver.

Change-Id: I2a650c8ae70189b738937eaea7e5cd28f896257c
Implements: blueprint iscsi-multipath-enhancement
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/81/134681/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_get_iscsi_properties_multiple_portals(self): volume = {"provider_location": '1.1.1.1:3260;2.2.2.2:3261,1 iqn:iqn 0', "id": "0", "provider_auth": "a b c", "attached_mode": "rw"} iscsi_driver = self.base_driver(configuration=self.configuration) result = iscsi_driver._get_iscsi_properties(volume) self.assertEqual(result["target_portal"], "1.1.1.1:3260") self.assertEqual(result["target_portal_secondary"], ["2.2.2.2:3261"]) self.assertEqual(result["target_iqn"], "iqn:iqn") self.assertEqual(result["target_iqn_secondary"], ["iqn:iqn"]) self.assertEqual(result["target_lun"], 0) self.assertEqual(result["target_lun_secondary"], [0])

commit_message:
Migrate postgresql backend to use openstacklib::db::postgresql

Let migrate to the new openstacklib::db::postgresql helper for
postgresql backend. This commit also unpin postgresql fixture
(openstacklib support now the latest version of postgre module).

Change-Id: I632aa31dd664032b7d0bf7bed44a3c89f6981d10
Implements: blueprint commmon-openstack-database-resource

commit_message:
Makes kombu_ssl_* parameters optional when rabbit_use_ssl => true

The kombu_ssl_* parameters should not be required when rabbit_use_ssl => true
Rather, rabbit_use_ssl must be set to true if the kombu_ssl_* parameters are
used.

Change-Id: I5e138adea60d2dc8b398bb05896def8508cd9f44
Closes-Bug: 1356083
(cherry picked from commit 1c3fd4da9e329400e7c92196a8ddd6dd8b95dafe)

commit_message:
enable simple region definition in config.

Nova uses long format for describing regions in config -
region_list=ROne=IP1,RTwo=IP2

this change enables simple definition without IP(mostly used for devstack instalation)
region_list=RegionOne

Change-Id: I2d2d4d111df6bb21ddc02d4341d8a9a726300e36

commit_message:
Prevent races in opportunistic db test cases

Previously opportunistic db test cases used to share openstack_citest
database among all test cases, which could be run concurrently in
different test running processes.

With recent changes made to our CI, we now can create and drop
database schemas on demand in tests. Providing each opportunistic db
test case with its own DB will effectively prevent possible races.

Related-Bug: #1288916

Conflicts:
	openstack/common/db/sqlalchemy/test_base.py

Change-Id: I7f6e272eaeb776b6a645ba502853892e79312afd
(cherry picked from commit 54f7e7f9b26b46a7ef9ef0de50187c06d6a424be)

subject: Prevent races in opportunistic db test cases
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-18 18:33:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/64df9f3c2273006002db097383cd9741bb453c80', 'message': "Prevent races in opportunistic db test cases

Opportunistic db test cases create schemas on demand, so that each
test case which inherits the base test case class, will get its own
db schema (i. e. races between tests are not possible).

In order to do schema provisioning we have to connect to RDBMS server
first. So far we've been connecting to the openstack_citest database,
which is guaranteed to exist on CI nodes. It turns out, there are a
few test cases in Nova (maybe in other projects as well), that drop
and recreate the openstack_citest database. If they happen to do that
when the opportunistic db fixture is in the middle of provisioning a
schema, those tests will fail (as there is an an open session to the
database and thus it can't be dropped).

This can be solved easily by changing the way we provision new
schemas in opportunistic db test cases as actually, we don't have to
connect to the openstack_citest database at all:

 - for MySQL we can use an empty db name to connect to MySQL server,
   but not to a particular database
 - PostgreSQL requires us to specify the database name. We can use
   the service postgres database here (PostgreSQL shell utils such
   as createdb, createuser, etc use it for the very same reason)

Closes-Bug: #1328997

Change-Id: Id82090743e8b93f6c960de066fd05d8a2f9fb934
(cherry picked from commit 11273cfe53e1069ff2a233c74f2559ea7c68943c)

commit_message:
Prevent races in opportunistic db test cases

Opportunistic db test cases create schemas on demand, so that each
test case which inherits the base test case class, will get its own
db schema (i. e. races between tests are not possible).

In order to do schema provisioning we have to connect to RDBMS server
first. So far we've been connecting to the openstack_citest database,
which is guaranteed to exist on CI nodes. It turns out, there are a
few test cases in Nova (maybe in other projects as well), that drop
and recreate the openstack_citest database. If they happen to do that
when the opportunistic db fixture is in the middle of provisioning a
schema, those tests will fail (as there is an an open session to the
database and thus it can't be dropped).

This can be solved easily by changing the way we provision new
schemas in opportunistic db test cases as actually, we don't have to
connect to the openstack_citest database at all:

 - for MySQL we can use an empty db name to connect to MySQL server,
   but not to a particular database
 - PostgreSQL requires us to specify the database name. We can use
   the service postgres database here (PostgreSQL shell utils such
   as createdb, createuser, etc use it for the very same reason)

Closes-Bug: #1328997

Change-Id: Id82090743e8b93f6c960de066fd05d8a2f9fb934
(cherry picked from commit 11273cfe53e1069ff2a233c74f2559ea7c68943c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/59/115059/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DBNAME = '' # connect to MySQL server, but not to the openstack_citest db DBNAME = 'postgres' # PostgreSQL requires the db name here,use service one

commit_message:
Add warning to sqlalchemy backend size limit docs

Partial-Bug: #1416088

Change-Id: I21bde00445892a4c734592cbcc143f23085e5660
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/43/153443/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. warning:: Currently there is a size limit (not applicable for ``sqlite``) that the ``results`` will contain. This size limit will restrict how many prior failures a retry atom can contain. More information and a future fix will be posted to bug `1416088`_ (for the meantime try to ensure that your retry units history does not grow beyond ~80 prior results). .. _1416088: http://bugs.launchpad.net/taskflow/+bug/1416088

subject: Add a capturing listener (for test or other usage)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-02 20:54:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/dee23feec2a4323cafc252fc739d773e6d4514b5', 'message': "Add a capturing listener (for test or other usage)

To enable those that are using taskflow to easily attach
to an engine (say in a unit test) and capture all the transitions,
details and state changes in a accumulating 'values' list provide
a capturing listener that does just this (and change the one used
for internal testing to use it) so that others may also benefit
from the same functionality.

commit_message:
Add a capturing listener (for test or other usage)

To enable those that are using taskflow to easily attach
to an engine (say in a unit test) and capture all the transitions,
details and state changes in a accumulating 'values' list provide
a capturing listener that does just this (and change the one used
for internal testing to use it) so that others may also benefit
from the same functionality.

Change-Id: I7a35e282dd4a6b3e14277bea2af1f275615bd212

added_lines: from taskflow.listeners import capturingclass CaptureListener(capturing.CaptureListener): _LOOKUP_NAME_POSTFIX = { capturing.CaptureListener.TASK: ('.t', 'task_name'), capturing.CaptureListener.RETRY: ('.r', 'retry_name'), capturing.CaptureListener.FLOW: ('.f', 'flow_name'), } def _format_capture(self, kind, state, details): name_postfix, name_key = self._LOOKUP_NAME_POSTFIX[kind] name = details[name_key] + name_postfix
deleted_lines: from taskflow.listeners import base as listener_baseclass CaptureListener(listener_base.Listener): _LOOKUP_NAME_POSTFIX = { 'task_name': '.t', 'retry_name': '.r', 'flow_name': '.f', } def __init__(self, engine, task_listen_for=listener_base.DEFAULT_LISTEN_FOR, values=None, capture_flow=True, capture_task=True, capture_retry=True, skip_tasks=None, skip_retries=None, skip_flows=None): super(CaptureListener, self).__init__(engine, task_listen_for=task_listen_for) self._capture_flow = capture_flow self._capture_task = capture_task self._capture_retry = capture_retry self._skip_tasks = skip_tasks or [] self._skip_flows = skip_flows or [] self._skip_retries = skip_retries or [] if values is None: self.values = [] else: self.values = values def _capture(self, state, details, name_key): name = details[name_key] try: name += self._LOOKUP_NAME_POSTFIX[name_key] except KeyError: pass def _task_receiver(self, state, details): if self._capture_task: if details['task_name'] not in self._skip_tasks: self.values.append(self._capture(state, details, 'task_name')) def _retry_receiver(self, state, details): if self._capture_retry: if details['retry_name'] not in self._skip_retries: self.values.append(self._capture(state, details, 'retry_name')) def _flow_receiver(self, state, details): if self._capture_flow: if details['flow_name'] not in self._skip_flows: self.values.append(self._capture(state, details, 'flow_name'))

commit_message:
Bump up the env_builder.sh to 2.7.9

The latest python 2.x release is 2.7.9 and not
2.7.7 so when people are using this script to build
a useful environment (that is lacking py2.7) use this
newer version instead.

Change-Id: I2fdd035e0b4efcacd6ef2da04d6cd8a56dcca512

commit_message:
Default to using a thread-safe storage unit

Instead of having a nominally useful single-threaded storage
unit that uses a dummy r/w lock and a multi-threaded storage
unit just have the storage unit by default protect itself from
multi-threading calls being used on it (with the appropriate
reader/writer locks being activated to make this work
correctly).

Change-Id: Ib6879edb465156a8e54fd5b4002550d1cec49137

commit_message:
Change oslo.* to oslo_*

Change oslo.db to oslo_db
Change oslo.config to olso_config
Change oslo.rootwrap to oslo_rootwrap

The oslo libraries are moving away from namespace packages.

Partial-bug: 1409733

Change-Id: I3429282afa2db4c0b3aa630eb3a0eaece04405ed

commit_message:
Add sort support to image list

Add sort support to image list by sorting items in the client side.
The parameter syntax follows this spec[1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/145544/

Change-Id: I42b487d18f00f937db1938daa46487cea2a896ab
Closes-Bug: #1410251

added_lines: def get_field(item, field): try: if isinstance(item, dict): return item[field] else: return getattr(item, field) except Exception: msg = "Resource doesn't have field %s" % field raise exceptions.CommandError(msg) def sort_items(items, sort_str): sort_keys = sort_str.strip().split(',') msg = "Specify sort direction by asc or desc" for sort_key in reversed(sort_keys): reverse = False if ':' in sort_key: sort_key, direction = sort_key.split(':', 1) if direction not in ['asc', 'desc']: raise exceptions.CommandError(msg) if direction == 'desc': reverse = True items = sorted(items, key=lambda item: get_field(item, sort_key), reverse=reverse) return items

commit_message:
improve iSCSI connection check

This patch improves the iSCSI connection verification by polling
/dev/disk/by-path for the iSCSI connection. This should ensure that
the iSCSI block device is seen by the file system after login.

It also removes the hard coded sleep in the login method.

Change-Id: Ibf6b6a15471a6130f33788b8c3f26d4577bf79a3
Closes-bug: #1417307

commit_message:
Add the subnet creation step to the install guide

Currently the subnet creation step is not documented
in the baremetal installation guide. This is a necessary
step and should be included

Change-Id: I20e5ecd982ae724d653a2bdf89ea86527df57dff
Closes-bug: #1418659

commit_message:
Cleanup code and remove newly ignored hack rules

newer hacking has rules for the following:
  H105  Don't use author tags
  H238  old style class declaration, use new style (inherit from `object`)
  W292 no newline at end of file

So we need to clean them up and stop ignoring them

Change-Id: I12b995cf87d6bc0938298f397b41a4693627bb4b

commit_message:
Keep up with the global requirements

docker-py and python-kubernetes are the only ones not in the
global requirements list. We should sync up the versions of
the rest of the libraries.

Change-Id: I0eff3ddecb80f057bb4998a48c8b32b3c1cf8b00

commit_message:
Change command for creating a virtualenv

echo "Done" seems to give people the wrong impression that
something went wrong. Just run python -V to print the python
version instead.

Closes-Bug: #1412223
Change-Id: I72d47fd2f1bf99ea13047598ead5df0fe8fa42ff

commit_message:
Fix correct puppet modules names

- Deleted puppet-galera because it's not used.
- Renamed all Puppetlabs modules with 'puppetlabs-' name instead of 'puppet-'

Change-Id: Ib7855cbc145d8c67a550a9f04a6067668b11dc18
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

Add new Puppet Modules

- puppetlabs-corosync
- puppet_aviator
- puppet-openstacklib
- puppet-openstack_extras

Change-Id: I09eda255e3c1567fc5d4d5e47d83ac0f6ccdabb2
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -eux mkdir -p /opt/puppet/modules export MODULEPATH=/opt/puppet/modules # Other Dependencies puppet module install -v '>=3.0.0 <4.0.0' 'puppetlabs/ntp' puppet module install -v '>=1.0.0 <2.0.0' 'puppetlabs/firewall' puppet module install -v '>=0.2.0 <1.0.0' 'puppetlabs/vswitch' puppet module install -v '>=0.6.0 <1.0.0' 'puppetlabs/mongodb' puppet module install -v '>=2.2.0 <3.0.0' 'puppetlabs/mysql' puppet module install -v '>=3.0.0 <4.0.0' 'puppetlabs/rabbitmq' puppet module install -v '>=1.0.0 <1.2.0' 'puppetlabs/apache' # Latest sysctl is broken with 0440 permission, so pin to 0.0.1 (with 0444) puppet module install -v '0.0.1' 'duritong/sysctl' ## OpenStack Dependencies os_projects=" keystone swift cinder glance neutron nova heat ceilometer horizon" for project in $os_projects do git clone https://git.openstack.org/stackforge/puppet-$project /opt/puppet/modules/$project done # TODO # Make sure /opt/puppet/modules is in modulepath (are environment directories in play?)
